Thanks for updating. 

The loga make the perfect sense. This log shows, you either face the network bandwidth issue, or most likely, your OAP and/or storage cluster are not powerful enough, so they are rejecting the data from the agents. 

DEADLINE_EXCEEDED is the TCP/HTTP timeout.

I see no indication of excessive load on our OAP/MySQL setup:
```CONTAINER ID   NAME                                                    CPU %     MEM USAGE / LIMIT     MEM %     NET I/O          BLOCK I/O        PIDS
564018904e27   opendistro_skywalking-oap.1.4hp84jt9s1nyoa5k3qq2rwdhz   9.00%     2.904GiB / 31.26GiB   9.29%     102GB / 50.2GB   2.71GB / 0B      145
e5c4793b468d   opendistro_mysql.1.9piq2ne1gllwln0ax9jso3ueb            60.51%    5.886GiB / 31.26GiB   18.83%    48.5GB / 24GB    804GB / 4.49TB   69
```
The host is 8x core CPU and 32GB RAM.  (cpu usage range reported by docker is thus 0%-800%).
 
Is there any additional tuning that could be done ? Also, it is indicative we experienced the issue after the upgrade to 8.3.0 ...

Check your Disk IO of the storage please.
We don't change many about this part. 
My understanding this should relate to mysql performance, the traffic of monitored services, sampling rate, etc.
可以将 skywalking 的 traceId 设置在Sleuth 的 Baggage中传递下来，在原日志同时打印 slueth 的 traceId 以及 在Baggage 中记录的 skywalking 的 traceId

Could you share which class(es) are you referring? 

About the leak, it may not leak, but the agent wouldn't work, and cost some but limited extra memory.

Yes, generally speaking, it only takes up more memory. Moreover, if the configuration of the custom enhance plugin is not at the end of the call chain, it will have the opportunity to be removed by the after method of other plugins.

But it would be better if the risk was fixed.

In addition, I think this configuration of  close_ after_ method can be removed, after all, close_ after_ Method does nothing special except to release the object.
@zhaoyuguang Could you take a look at this config? I am not sure about what are these configs for.

Q1:Yes, On a synchronous thread，createSpan count > stopSpan count will be ML.
Q2: `close_before_method` mean : the timing of method execution, before enhance method

OK, Thanks! 
@wu-sheng @zhaoyuguang

> I just did a direct call with @zhaoyuguang
> 
> @gaoweijie I think these 2 parameters are the case of over-design, which makes things too complex. We agree, we should remove these 2 parameters, and also create span before method, and stop after that.
> Do you have interest to do this and send a pull request to upstream?

Yes, I am glad to fix this risk.

Now `Custom Plugin` is overdesign, I recommend that Custom Plugin only focus on synchronous threading model and Local Span. if that, createSpan and stopSpan are performed at the beginning of a method closure, the ML risk is lower and the configuration is easier
Please keep this branch after merge. I will delete it after all release process finished.
Please update the changelog of project section.

> I gave this a look and try. The only things I've noticed that seem problematic is that `uuid` is not guaranteed to be unique. You can re-use the same `uuid` and the event system will accept it. 

At OAP side, we choose to adopt the strategy "two records for one event" because we don't want to do updates for time series data like this. "Two records for one event" results in that no guarantee on the uniqueness of uuid at db level. If the users use the same UUIDs then the events should be considered as a single event according to our protocol. 

> Also, the `queryEvents` endpoint allows you to not define the start/end/step. I don't think other endpoints allow you not to specify the time range. Seems like it should be required.

I'm not sure about the fact of what you said. Requiring those is easy at protocol level, though we may not want to use them when there is no necessity (e.g. when you have a uuid while the time is unsure but you have to give one). 

> Also, I don't seem to be able to update events. The following two commands:
> 
> ```
> 
> ./swctl-latest-linux-amd64 event r --uuid uuid3 --service service --name name --message message --startTime 1612225542333
> 
> ./swctl-latest-linux-amd64 event r --uuid uuid3 --service service --name name --message message --startTime 1612225542333 --endTime 1612225542333
> 
> ```
> 
> 
> 
> Results in:
> 
> ```
> 
> {
> 
>   "data": {
> 
>     "result": {
> 
>       "events": [
> 
>         {
> 
>           "name": "name",
> 
>           "source": {
> 
>             "service": "service",
> 
>             "serviceInstance": "",
> 
>             "endpoint": ""
> 
>           },
> 
>           "startTime": 1612225542333,
> 
>           "endTime": 0,
> 
>           "message": "message",
> 
>           "parameters": [],
> 
>           "uuid": "uuid3"
> 
>         }
> 
>       ]
> 
>     }
> 
>   }
> 
> }
> 
> ```

That must be a bug if it is really the case, which I don't think so, if you are using ElasticSearch as storage, attention that the writes are async and may need some time to flush them to ES, can you try some time later after the CLI commands? (e.g. 30 seconds or so).

> 
> I'm using skywalking-cli @ https://github.com/apache/skywalking-cli/commit/ae085deb32434a0859e49c45819fed7a5c4010b5. It also seems a bit odd that you have to set `Required flags "uuid, service, name, message, startTime"` even when updating an event. All that should be necessary is the `uuid` as the other fields may have already been set.
> 

@fgksgf can you please re-organize the flags' verification? Let's remove all `required` and do composite verifications later.

> Finally, there does not seem to be a way to set event parameters via skywalking-cli.

The parameters are set as arguments, i.e. `./swctl-latest-linux-amd64 event r --uuid uuid3 --service service --name name --message message --startTime 1612225542333 --endTime 1612225542333 key1=value key2=value2`

@kezhenxu94, my thinking was that if you don't include the `uuid` then you have to include other conditions. If having the ability to return all events is something that's at least non-detrimental then go ahead. It just seemed odd that you can't get all logs, all traces, or all metrics so it seemed to make sense not to be able to get all events.

As for the non-updating issue, I'm not using ES. I'm able to produce that issue on H2.
8.4 is still on voting, and you didn't follow the compiling documentation. `Download` button on the GitHub is not suitable option for SkyWalking.
And this part you mentioned, AFAIK, nothing changed there.

Before tag, we need to add sampling mechanism, at least 2 kinds for per service. We need a cache for holding this sampling status in the runtime.
1. Sample N(max) per minute for each internal error code. 
2. Sample M(max) per minute for not-internal error, which means service error or network error(at client side)

About cache itself,  I think caffeine has better performance(please check the benchmark), but we don't use it in the core yet. Zipkin receiver uses it, so, it is already in the classpath and dependencies.

Back the tag, I think internal error code and HTTP response code are reasonable tags at least.
